text: You will now begin the first part of the experiment. This task should take you approximately 8-10 minutes to complete. Please pay close attention to the following instructions.
In this study, you will see lotteries like the one pictured on this screen. Each lottery represents a real bag with 100 poker chips in it (some red and some blue).

The number of red and blue chips inside the bag is represented by the size of the red and blue bars and the numbers written inside them. In this example, most chips are blue (75 out of 100), and fewer are red (25 out of 100).

This means that if you were to draw a poker chip at random from this bag, you would be more likely to draw a blue one than a red one. If you decided to play this lottery, the computer would draw a chip at random from a lottery containing 75 blue chips and 25 red chips at the end of the study. The color of the chip you draw will determine how much money you earn.

Above and below each bar is a number indicating a dollar amount, which represents how much money you could earn in that lottery. If you play this lottery and draw a blue chip, you will get an additional $10.00. If you draw a red chip instead, you will get $0.

Please note that the colors may be associated with different monetary amounts in each lottery, such that the blue chips will sometimes represent getting $0, and the red chips will sometimes represent getting $0.

On some trials, part of the bar will be hidden, and you will only have partial information about the number of red and blue chips inside the bag.
For example, in this lottery, you can see that there are 25 blue chips and 25 red chips.

On these lottery trials, you only have partial information. The box over the lottery is covering up the remaining 50 chips. These chips could be all red, all blue, or any combination of red and blue.

On each trial, you will be asked to choose between two options using the [F] and [J] keys, which correspond to the left and right options. For example, you can either earn a guaranteed $5.00, or play the lottery for the $ amount indicated above the bar, where the odds of winning are indicated by the number of chips at the top of the bar (in this case there is a 75% chance of winning $10.00).

Keep in mind that the side the certain $5.00 or lottery appears on will switch throughout the task.

On the partial information trials, you will also be asked to choose between the guarenteed $5.00 or the lottery.

However, remember that on these trials you only have partial information about what your chances of winning are. For example, on this trial your chances of winning the lottery for $10.00 could be anywhere between 25% or 75% because 50 chips are covered.

If this phase of the experiment is selected to determine your bonus payment, the computer will randomly select one of your trials to pay you for! Based on your decision on that trial, we will either pay you the certain $5.00 (if that is what you chose on that trial) or the computer will play the lottery on your behalf for the lottery amount on that trial. For example, if you had a 75% chance of winning $10.00, the computer will draw a chip and you will be paid for that trial if the lottery is won!

If you understand all task instructions please click the “Quiz” button below. You must answer all 3 quiz questions correctly to ensure that you understand the nature of the task. Once you answer all 3 quiz questions correctly you will enter the practice phase of this section. Otherwise, you will be redirected to the task instructions for additional review.
